newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Chronology of Singapore elections since 1965.
newsitem.headline: Chronology of Singapore elections since 1965.

text.p: Singaporeans voted on Thursday for the country's ninth parliament. Following is a chronology of Singapore's election results and related events since independence in 1965:
April 13, 1968: The People's Action Party (PAP) of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew wins all 58 seats (84.4 percent of votes) in general election (51 seats uncontested). Voter turnout: 759,367.
September 2, 1972: PAP wins all 65 seats (69 percent of votes) in general election (eight seats uncontested). Voter turnout: 907,559.
September 3, 1976: Parliamentary Membership Bill (1976) eliminates six constituencies and creates 10. Number of constituencies grows to 69.
December 23, 1976: PAP wins all 69 seats (72.4 percent of votes) in general elections (16 seats uncontested). Voter turnout 1,095,817.
July 29, 1980: Parliamentary Membership Bill (1980) increases number of constituencies to 75.
December 23, 1980: PAP wins all 75 seats (75.6 percent of votes) in general election (37 seats uncontested). Voter turnout: 1,298,170.
October 31, 1981: PAP's 13-year monopoly on parliamentary seats ends when Workers Party (WP) leader Joshua Jeyaretnam wins by-election with 51.9 percent of vote (7,012 to 6,359).
December 22, 1984: PAP wins 77 seats out of 79 (62.9 percent of vote) in general election (30 seats uncontested). WP and Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) win one seat each.

September 3, 1988: PAP sweeps 80 seats out of 81 (63.2 percent of votes) at stake in general elections (11 seats uncontested). Opposition contests highest-ever 70 seats. SDP leader Chiam See Tong claims remaining seat.
August 31, 1991: PAP wins 77 seats out of 81 (447,760 votes) in general elections (41 seats uncontested). SDP wins three seats and WP one.
October 28, 1996: Parliament passes bills changing electoral boundaries and increasing the number of seats to 83.
December 23, 1996: PAP secures parliamentary majority on nomination day ahead of January 2 voting after opposition decides to contest just 36 seats.
